episode.content: The coronavirus has led to a rise in home dining. And as a result people are more concerned about what they put into their bodies. Amid this trend, produce from small scale farms is becoming increasingly popular. Consumers are able to buy fresh vegetables direct from farmers, via the Internet. And the products are often grown in a safer, more environmentally friendly way than those that are mass-produced. For farmers, the system not only offers greater profits, but the opportunity to make a contribution toward a sustainable future for society. We take a look at some examples in Japan. Guests: Akimoto Rina (Founder of a direct sales platform for produce) Miyata Hiroaki (Professor, Keio University) Sekine Kae (Associate Professor, Aichi Gakuin University) *Today's Close-Up will continue to report on COVID-19.
episode.description: As the pandemic changes societal values, small scale farming is increasingly seen as a viable new lifestyle. We look at how the agriculture sector is leading the push for a sustainable world.
episode.subtitle: Small Scale Farming: A Lifestyle for the Post-Pandemic World
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: Japan's hanko seals have been an essential requirement for day-to-day documents and official forms for many years. But a government push to bring workplace practices and administrative procedures fully into the digital era has put pressure on businesses and city authorities to eliminate the seals from most paperwork. We look at what the shift away from this long-running custom means for Japan, and some of the hurdles that are presenting themselves along the way. Guests: Atsugiri Jason (Tech firm executive/Comedian) Watanabe Yuichiro (Member of the Board, Japan In-House Lawyers Association) Miyata Hiroaki (Professor, Keio University)
episode.description: The use of hanko seals on official forms and documents is deeply ingrained in Japanese culture. But a society-wide shift to digital work practices is forcing many to question the need for them.
episode.subtitle: How Will Japan Change Without "Hanko"?
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: The Tokyo Olympic Games are due to open in eight months' time, but can they really be held while the coronavirus pandemic shows no sign of ending? An international gymnastics competition held in Tokyo in early November was used as a test event. The organizers took strict anti-infection measures, but were troubled by a series of unexpected problems. NHK went behind the scenes to see what will be necessary to safely hold the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games. Guest: Kaku Mitsuo (Specially Appointed Professor, Tohoku Medical and Pharmaceutical University)
episode.description: What difficulties await the organizers of the Tokyo Olympic Games next year because of the coronavirus pandemic? We look behind the scenes of an international gymnastics meet held as a test in Tokyo.
episode.subtitle: Are the Tokyo Games Possible? - Int'l Gymnastics Meet Held as Test
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: In the latest Global Gender Gap Index survey, Japan came 121st out of 153 countries, and was the lowest among major advanced nations. The government is aiming to have women in 30 percent of leadership roles by 2020, but the figure currently stands at just 14.8 percent. What does Japanese society need to do to change this? Overcoming "unconscious bias" might be the answer. NHK took a close look at how some companies are trying to tackle this issue to find out the key to creating a workplace where women can shine. Guests: Takeishi Emiko (Professor, Hosei University) Miyata Hiroaki (Professor, Keio University)
episode.description: Unconscious biases are regarded as one of the main factors behind the struggle to get women to play more active roles in Japanese companies. We take a look at the effort to overcome them.
episode.subtitle: A Workplace Where Women Can Shine: Overcoming Innate Gender Bias
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: More than 1,300 farm animals, including pigs, calves, and goats, were stolen this summer in Japan's Kanto region. During the investigation, local police arrested a group of Vietnamese nationals on suspicion of overstaying their visas. Their connection to the thefts is still unclear but NHK followed a trail of social media posts advertising butchered pigs. We learned about the tough situation faced by Vietnamese technical trainees, and how the pandemic is making things even more difficult.
episode.description: Recent reports of stolen farm animals north of Tokyo shed light on the increasingly tough situation faced by Vietnamese technical trainees in Japan. We take a deeper look at their plight.
episode.subtitle: In Search of the Stolen Pigs: The Plight of Vietnamese Technical Trainees
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: On December 6, Japan's Hayabusa2 probe successfully returned a capsule to Earth after a six-year voyage through space. It is believed to contain sub-surface materials collected on Ryugu, an asteroid some 300-million kilometers away. They may shed light on the origins of life on Earth. The mission faced a series of unexpected challenges and NHK went behind the scenes to see how the team achieved the extraordinary feat of two touchdowns on Ryugu and the safe return of the sample container. Guests: Tsuda Yuichi (Hayabusa2 Project Manager) Terazono Junya (Former member, Hayabusa project team)
episode.description: Japan's Hayabusa2 mission has achieved a world-first by returning samples of sub-surface material from an asteroid. We take an in-depth look at how the project team overcame unexpected difficulties.
episode.subtitle: Hayabusa2: Secrets of Japan's Asteroid Mission
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: Japan is currently experiencing a sharp spike in coronavirus infections, leading the government to declare a second state of emergency. Hospital beds are filling up and in one case, a patient was rejected by 24 emergency care facilities. At the same time, new strains from around the world present the threat of a further surge. We take a look at how experts are using the latest data and technology to avoid a worst-case scenario. Guest: Hamada Atsuo (Professor, Tokyo Medical University) *Today's Close-Up will continue to report on COVID-19.
episode.description: As coronavirus strains from around the world threaten an unprecedented surge in cases, experts in Japan are struggling to come up with adequate preventive measures. We take a look at their efforts.
episode.subtitle: How to Prevent Worst-Case COVID-19 Surge: Latest Findings Provide the Key
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: Japan is in the midst of a third wave of coronavirus infections, the worst yet. The collapse of the medical system could soon become reality. With beds in short supply, ambulances transporting patients are increasingly being turned away from hospitals. Many people have no choice but to recuperate at home, anxiously monitoring for a sudden deterioration in their conditions. We ask medical experts how Japan can bring the situation under control. Guest: Ogura Takayuki (COO, Japan ECMOnet for COVID-19) *Today's Close-Up will continue to report on COVID-19.
episode.description: A surge in COVID-19 cases across Japan is straining hospitals and pushing the medical system to the brink of collapse. We ask experts what the government can do to avert a crisis and save lives.
episode.subtitle: Frontline of COVID-19 Fight: An Escalating Medical Crisis
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: Japan's izakaya dining bars have always been places for people to enjoy a cozy drink and a bite to eat with friends. It's a dining culture that attracts overseas tourists too. But the coronavirus pandemic has the industry up against a wall. Some izakaya have transitioned into barbecue restaurants with robot servers, while others now specialize in take-out and delivery. A major worry is how to safeguard jobs in an industry where most of the workers are part-timers. NHK's cameras followed one major izakaya chain to document its efforts to survive. Guests: Asagi Kuniko (TV personality) Ishii Kota (Writer)
episode.description: Japan's izakaya dining bars are loved by workers and students alike, but the ongoing pandemic has put business at risk. We go behind the scenes of a major chain as it works out a way to survive.
episode.subtitle: Goodbye, Izakaya? Japanese Pubs at Crossroads
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: Stock investment apps are becoming popular in Japan as share prices surge during the pandemic. Some even allow people to use reward points earned through everyday cashless payments to become shareholders. Such mobile investors could become a driving force in the market, as the case of Robinhood showed in the US. How will this new trend change our lives and the economy at a time when the world is trying to bounce back from the coronavirus? Guests: Nagi Rei (Researcher, Youth research unit, Dentsu) Iwashita Naoyuki (Professor, Kyoto University School of Government)
episode.description: A vast range of financial services from payments and loan financing to investment is becoming available through smartphone apps. We take a look at these developments being accelerated by the pandemic.
episode.subtitle: Mobile Finance Revolution Driven by Pandemic
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: The coronavirus pandemic has hit Japan's vulnerable teenagers especially hard. Some have been forced to take jobs to support their cash-strapped parents. Others have found themselves cooped up in stressful home environments as a result of stay-at-home requests. We spent time at a school attended by many struggling teens and documented the efforts of teachers and other staff to assist them as they make the transition beyond graduation into society. Guest: Ishii Kota (Writer)
episode.description: The pandemic has hit vulnerable teenagers hard, forcing them to work to support their parents and to spend more time in troubled home environments. We look at what some schools are doing to help.
episode.subtitle: Pandemic Hits Troubled Teens
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: On February 1st, Myanmar's military shocked the world by staging a coup. In the weeks since, civilian protests have continued to grow. Many countries have denounced the military's actions but China has maintained its policy of non-interference. Meanwhile, Japan is in a unique position, with strong ties to both the military and democratic leaders. How will the country respond to the situation? We talk to an expert about the growing impact of the protests. Guest: Nakanishi Yoshihiro (Associate Professor, Center for Southeast Asian Studies, Kyoto University)
episode.description: Weeks of widespread civilian protests have followed a military coup in Myanmar. The political turmoil is starting to affect foreign businesses in the country. We take a deeper look at the situation.
episode.subtitle: Myanmar Coup: Future of the Protests
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: The 2011 earthquake and tsunami transformed some Japanese townships in just minutes, taking thousands of lives, and leaving behind many grieving survivors. In one town, storytellers on a bus tour honor the legacy of both groups by sharing their experiences and passing on their memories to visitors. The program follows the same route with detailed visual simulations of the tsunami to show how people acted to save their lives and the lives of others. Guest: Ito Shun (Storyteller, hotel employee)
episode.description: Ten years after one of Japan's worst ever natural disasters, the 2011 earthquake and tsunami, a bus storytelling tour preserves and passes on the traumatic experiences of those who lived and died.
episode.subtitle: Storytelling Bus Tour: 2011 Tsunami Survivors Keep Memories Alive
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: On March 11, 2011, a huge earthquake and tsunami struck northeastern Japan, taking thousands of lives. Ten years on, a father continues to dive in the sea, looking for his missing daughter. At night, his wife records her memories of their daughter on paper. She says "I try not to move on too quickly so the memories won't fade away." We report on a couple who lost their precious child so suddenly and how they have spent the past decade.
episode.description: More than 2,500 people went missing in the tsunami that hit northeastern Japan in 2011. This is a report about a father who continues diving in the sea in search of his missing daughter.
episode.subtitle: Diving for a Missing Daughter: Ten Years After 3.11 Tsunami
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: Live commerce, combining online shopping with live-streamed sales pitches, is rapidly expanding its reach around the world. Expensive items are selling like hot cakes despite the pandemic. The tide is rising fastest in China, which already has some 400-million live commerce shoppers. Retailers from major department stores to big home appliance shops are now getting in on the act. We take a look at the trend and the value the new shopping style provides to consumers. Guests: Takata Akira (Founder, Japanet Takata) Maeda Yuji (CEO, SHOWROOM)
episode.description: Live streaming e-commerce has been booming during the pandemic, forging into new markets around the world. Why is this way of selling proving so popular? We take a look at how the trend is developing.
episode.subtitle: Live Streaming E-commerce: Sales Booming During the Pandemic
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: It's been more than a year since the start of the coronavirus pandemic. An NHK survey has found that thousands of children in Japan have missed school due to virus-related health concerns. At the same time, major cities and municipalities have been slow to roll out online learning programs. As a result, many of these "voluntarily absent" students are falling behind their peers. We asked them to describe their experiences of the past year, and how they feel about spending so much time away from the classroom. Guest: Suetomi Kaori (Professor, Nihon University)
episode.description: More than 7,000 students in Japan have missed time from school due to coronavirus-related health concerns. We take a look at the challenges they face as they try to keep up with their classmates.
episode.subtitle: Lost Education: "Voluntarily Absent" During the Pandemic
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: How is it possible that people who share homes with members of their own family can die lonely deaths and go undiscovered for days or even longer? To find out, NHK looked at a series of such tragic cases across Japan. We delved deeply into one, involving a man who initially failed to notice his father's death, then lived with the body for months. Our conversations with him uncovered a story of broken ties and work-related stress, which ended with the man and his father leading completely separate lives while sharing the same roof. Guest: Shigematsu Kiyoshi (Author)
episode.description: Cases where the deaths of people go unnoticed by cohabiting family members are raising troubling questions. To find out more, NHK spoke with a man who lived with the body of his father for months.
episode.subtitle: Living with Family, but All Alone: Solitary Deaths in Japan
episode.title: Today's Close-Up

episode.content: The variant with the N501Y mutation, first confirmed in the UK is now rampant in Japan. Unlike previous strains, younger people in their thirties to sixties have a higher risk of becoming gravely ill. In Osaka, one of Japan's largest cities, the medical system is overwhelmed and people are dying at home due to a lack of available beds. Meanwhile, the central government says vaccinating the elderly must be finished by the end of July, but will the municipalities responsible be able to meet the deadline? We take a look at the frontline in the battle with the changing coronavirus. Guest: Kutsuna Satoshi (National Center for Global Health and Medicine)
episode.description: New research into coronavirus variants reveals that conventional measures may not work and many people are becoming sicker more quickly. We have a frontline report on a healthcare system in crisis.
episode.subtitle: Coronavirus Variants Changing the Stakes
episode.title: Today's Close-Up
